paragraphs: Want to start a startup? Get funded by Y Combinator. August 2013The biggest component in most investors' opinion of you is the opinion of other investors. Which is of course a recipe for exponential growth.

When one investor wants to invest in you, that makes other investors want to, which makes others want to, and so on.Sometimes inexperienced founders mistakenly conclude that manipulating these forces is the essence of fundraising.
They hear stories about stampedes to invest in successful startups, and think it's therefore the mark of a successful startup to have this happen. But actually the two are not that highly correlated.

Lots of startups that cause stampedes end up flaming out (in extreme cases, partly as a result of the stampede), and lots of very successful startups were only moderately popular with investors the first time they raised money.So the point of this essay is not to explain how to create a stampede, but merely to explain the forces that generate them.

These forces are always at work to some degree in fundraising, and they can cause surprising situations. If you understand them, you can at least avoid being surprised.One reason investors like you more when other investors like you is that you actually become a better investment.

Raising money decreases the risk of failure. Indeed, although investors hate it, you are for this reason justified in raising your valuation for later investors. The investors who invested when you had no money were taking more risk, and are entitled to higher returns.

Plus a company that has raised money is literally more valuable. After you raise the first million dollars, the company is at least a million dollars more valuable, because it's the same company as before, plus it has a million dollars in the bank.

[1]Beware, though, because later investors so hate to have the price raised on them that they resist even this self-evident reasoning. Only raise the price on an investor you're comfortable with losing, because some will angrily refuse.

[2]The second reason investors like you more when you've had some success at fundraising is that it makes you more confident, and an investors' opinion of you is the foundation of their opinion of your company.

Founders are often surprised how quickly investors seem to know when they start to succeed at raising money. And while there are in fact lots of ways for such information to spread among investors, the main vector is probably the founders themselves.

Though they're often clueless about technology, most investors are pretty good at reading people. When fundraising is going well, investors are quick to sense it in your increased confidence. (This is one case where the average founder's inability to remain poker-faced works to your advantage.)But frankly the most important reason investors like you more when you've started to raise money is that they're bad at judging startups.

Judging startups is hard even for the best investors. The mediocre ones might as well be flipping coins. So when mediocre investors see that lots of other people want to invest in you, they assume there must be a reason.

This leads to the phenomenon known in the Valley as the "hot deal," where you have more interest from investors than you can handle.The best investors aren't influenced much by the opinion of other investors.

It would only dilute their own judgment to average it together with other people's. But they are indirectly influenced in the practical sense that interest from other investors imposes a deadline. This is the fourth way in which offers beget offers.

If you start to get far along the track toward an offer with one firm, it will sometimes provoke other firms, even good ones, to make up their minds, lest they lose the deal.Unless you're a wizard at negotiation (and if you're not sure, you're not) be very careful about exaggerating this to push a good investor to decide.

Founders try this sort of thing all the time, and investors are very sensitive to it. If anything oversensitive. But you're safe so long as you're telling the truth. If you're getting far along with investor B, but you'd rather raise money from investor A, you can tell investor A that this is happening.

There's no manipulation in that. You're genuinely in a bind, because you really would rather raise money from A, but you can't safely reject an offer from B when it's still uncertain what A will decide.Do not, however, tell A who B is.

VCs will sometimes ask which other VCs you're talking to, but you should never tell them. Angels you can sometimes tell about other angels, because angels cooperate more with one another. But if VCs ask, just point out that they wouldn't want you telling other firms about your conversations, and you feel obliged to do the same for any firm you talk to.

If they push you, point out that you're inexperienced at fundraising — which is always a safe card to play — and you feel you have to be extra cautious. [3]While few startups will experience a stampede of interest, almost all will at least initially experience the other side of this phenomenon, where the herd remains clumped together at a distance.

The fact that investors are so much influenced by other investors' opinions means you always start out in something of a hole. So don't be demoralized by how hard it is to get the first commitment, because much of the difficulty comes from this external force.

The second will be easier.Notes[1] An accountant might say that a company that has raised a million dollars is no richer if it's convertible debt, but in practice money raised as convertible debt is little different from money raised in an equity round.[2] Founders are often surprised by this, but investors can get very emotional.

Or rather indignant; that's the main emotion I've observed; but it is very common, to the point where it sometimes causes investors to act against their own interests. I know of one investor who invested in a startup at a $15 million valuation cap.

Earlier he'd had an opportunity to invest at a $5 million cap, but he refused because a friend who invested earlier had been able to invest at a $3 million cap.[3] If an investor pushes you hard to tell them about your conversations with other investors, is this someone you want as an investor?
Thanks to Paul Buchheit, Jessica Livingston, Geoff Ralston, and Garry Tan for reading drafts of this.Russian Translation

paragraphs.original: Want to start a startup? Get funded by Y Combinator. August 2013The biggest component in most investors' opinion of you is the opinion of other investors. Which is of course a recipe for exponential growth.
paragraphs.translated: 想创业吗？那就争取获得 Y Combinator 的投资吧。2013年8月，在大多数投资者对你的看法中，其他投资者的意见占了最大比重。这当然是一种促进指数增长的配方。

paragraphs.original: When one investor wants to invest in you, that makes other investors want to, which makes others want to, and so on.Sometimes inexperienced founders mistakenly conclude that manipulating these forces is the essence of fundraising.
paragraphs.translated: 当有一个投资者想要投资你时，这会让其他投资者也想投资，进而引发更多的投资者兴趣，依此类推。有时，缺乏经验的创始人会错误地认为操纵这些力量是融资的本质。

paragraphs.original: They hear stories about stampedes to invest in successful startups, and think it's therefore the mark of a successful startup to have this happen. But actually the two are not that highly correlated.
paragraphs.translated: 他们听到关于投资者蜂拥投资成功创业公司的故事，因此认为这种情况是成功创业公司的标志。但实际上，这两者之间的关联并不那么紧密。

paragraphs.original: Lots of startups that cause stampedes end up flaming out (in extreme cases, partly as a result of the stampede), and lots of very successful startups were only moderately popular with investors the first time they raised money.So the point of this essay is not to explain how to create a stampede, but merely to explain the forces that generate them.
paragraphs.translated: 许多造成热潮的初创公司最终都以失败告终（在极端情况下，部分原因是由于热潮本身），而许多非常成功的初创公司在首次融资时只得到了投资者的适度关注。因此，本文的目的是解释产生这些热潮的力量，而不是解释如何制造热潮。

paragraphs.original: These forces are always at work to some degree in fundraising, and they can cause surprising situations. If you understand them, you can at least avoid being surprised.One reason investors like you more when other investors like you is that you actually become a better investment.
paragraphs.translated: 这些力量在筹款过程中总是以某种程度存在，并可能导致令人惊讶的情况。如果你理解了它们，至少可以避免感到意外。投资者喜欢你的一个原因是，当其他投资者也喜欢你时，你实际上会成为一个更好的投资对象。

paragraphs.original: Raising money decreases the risk of failure. Indeed, although investors hate it, you are for this reason justified in raising your valuation for later investors. The investors who invested when you had no money were taking more risk, and are entitled to higher returns.
paragraphs.translated: 筹集资金降低了失败的风险。确实，尽管投资者不喜欢这样做，但你因此有理由在后续投资者面前提高估值。那些在你没有资金时就投资的人承担了更大的风险，理应获得更高的回报。

paragraphs.original: Plus a company that has raised money is literally more valuable. After you raise the first million dollars, the company is at least a million dollars more valuable, because it's the same company as before, plus it has a million dollars in the bank.
paragraphs.translated: 此外，筹集到资金的公司实际上更有价值。在你筹集到第一百万美元之后，公司的价值至少增加了百万美元，因为公司和之前一样，只是银行里多了一百万美元。

paragraphs.original: [1]Beware, though, because later investors so hate to have the price raised on them that they resist even this self-evident reasoning. Only raise the price on an investor you're comfortable with losing, because some will angrily refuse.
paragraphs.translated: 不过要小心，因为后期投资者非常不喜欢被提高价格，即使这种理由显而易见，他们也会抵制。只对那些你愿意失去的投资者提价，因为有些人会愤怒地拒绝。

paragraphs.original: [2]The second reason investors like you more when you've had some success at fundraising is that it makes you more confident, and an investors' opinion of you is the foundation of their opinion of your company.
paragraphs.translated: 投资者更喜欢你已经取得了一些融资成功的第二个原因是，这会让你更加自信，而投资者对你的看法是他们对公司看法的基础。

paragraphs.original: Founders are often surprised how quickly investors seem to know when they start to succeed at raising money. And while there are in fact lots of ways for such information to spread among investors, the main vector is probably the founders themselves.
paragraphs.translated: 创始人常常惊讶于投资者似乎很快就知道他们开始成功筹集资金了。虽然这类信息确实可以通过多种方式在投资者之间传播，但主要渠道可能是创始人自己。

paragraphs.original: Though they're often clueless about technology, most investors are pretty good at reading people. When fundraising is going well, investors are quick to sense it in your increased confidence. (This is one case where the average founder's inability to remain poker-faced works to your advantage.)But frankly the most important reason investors like you more when you've started to raise money is that they're bad at judging startups.
paragraphs.translated: 尽管他们通常对技术一窍不通，但大多数投资者在察言观色方面却相当在行。当融资进展顺利时，投资者会很快从你增强的自信中感受到这一点。（在这种情况下，普通创始人难以保持扑克脸的弱点反而成了你的优势。）但坦率地说，投资者在你开始筹集资金后更喜欢你的最重要原因是，他们在评估初创公司方面并不擅长。

paragraphs.original: Judging startups is hard even for the best investors. The mediocre ones might as well be flipping coins. So when mediocre investors see that lots of other people want to invest in you, they assume there must be a reason.
paragraphs.translated: 即使是最好的投资者，评判初创企业也是一件难事。平庸的投资者在这方面可能还不如抛硬币来得准确。因此，当这些平庸的投资者看到有很多人想投资你时，他们就会认为这其中一定有原因。

paragraphs.original: This leads to the phenomenon known in the Valley as the "hot deal," where you have more interest from investors than you can handle.The best investors aren't influenced much by the opinion of other investors.
paragraphs.translated: 这导致了在硅谷被称为“热门交易”的现象，即你收到的投资兴趣多到难以应付。最好的投资者并不会受到其他投资者意见的太大影响。

paragraphs.original: It would only dilute their own judgment to average it together with other people's. But they are indirectly influenced in the practical sense that interest from other investors imposes a deadline. This is the fourth way in which offers beget offers.
paragraphs.translated: 将他们的判断与他人的平均化只会削弱自己的判断。但在实际操作中，他们会受到其他投资者兴趣的影响，这种兴趣强加了一个期限。这是要约引发更多要约的第四种方式。

paragraphs.original: If you start to get far along the track toward an offer with one firm, it will sometimes provoke other firms, even good ones, to make up their minds, lest they lose the deal.Unless you're a wizard at negotiation (and if you're not sure, you're not) be very careful about exaggerating this to push a good investor to decide.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你在一个公司的投资意向谈判中进展顺利，有时这会促使其他公司，甚至是优秀的公司，加快决策，以免错失良机。除非你是一位谈判高手（如果你不确定自己是否是，那么你可能不是），在推动优秀投资者做出决定时，要非常小心不要夸大这种情况。

paragraphs.original: Founders try this sort of thing all the time, and investors are very sensitive to it. If anything oversensitive. But you're safe so long as you're telling the truth. If you're getting far along with investor B, but you'd rather raise money from investor A, you can tell investor A that this is happening.
paragraphs.translated: 创始人经常尝试这样做，而投资者对此非常敏感，甚至可以说过于敏感。但只要你讲的是实话，你就安全。如果你与投资者B的谈判进展顺利，但你更希望从投资者A那里获得资金，你可以告诉投资者A这一点。

paragraphs.original: There's no manipulation in that. You're genuinely in a bind, because you really would rather raise money from A, but you can't safely reject an offer from B when it's still uncertain what A will decide.Do not, however, tell A who B is.
paragraphs.translated: 这其中没有操纵。你确实陷入了困境，因为你确实更希望从A那里筹集资金，但在A的决定还不确定的情况下，你不能安全地拒绝B的offer。然而，不要告诉A谁是B。

paragraphs.original: VCs will sometimes ask which other VCs you're talking to, but you should never tell them. Angels you can sometimes tell about other angels, because angels cooperate more with one another. But if VCs ask, just point out that they wouldn't want you telling other firms about your conversations, and you feel obliged to do the same for any firm you talk to.
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资家有时会问你还在和哪些其他风险投资家交谈，但你永远不要告诉他们。对于天使投资人，有时你可以告诉他们你与其他天使投资人的交流，因为天使投资人之间合作更多。但如果风险投资家询问，只需指出他们也不会希望你向其他公司透露你们的对话内容，你觉得对任何你交谈的公司都有相同的义务。

paragraphs.original: If they push you, point out that you're inexperienced at fundraising — which is always a safe card to play — and you feel you have to be extra cautious. [3]While few startups will experience a stampede of interest, almost all will at least initially experience the other side of this phenomenon, where the herd remains clumped together at a distance.
paragraphs.translated: 如果他们施压，指出你缺乏筹款经验——这总是一张安全牌——并且你觉得自己必须格外谨慎。[3]尽管很少有初创公司会经历兴趣蜂拥而至的情况，但几乎所有的初创公司最初都会遇到这种现象的另一面，即大多数人依然保持距离，聚成一团。

paragraphs.original: The fact that investors are so much influenced by other investors' opinions means you always start out in something of a hole. So don't be demoralized by how hard it is to get the first commitment, because much of the difficulty comes from this external force.
paragraphs.translated: 投资者如此受其他投资者意见的影响，意味着你从一开始就在某种程度上处于不利地位。因此，不要因为获得第一个承诺如此困难而气馁，因为很多困难都源于这种外部力量。

paragraphs.original: The second will be easier.Notes[1] An accountant might say that a company that has raised a million dollars is no richer if it's convertible debt, but in practice money raised as convertible debt is little different from money raised in an equity round.[2] Founders are often surprised by this, but investors can get very emotional.
paragraphs.translated: 第二个会更容易。注释[1] 会计可能会说，如果是一家公司筹集的是一百万美元的可转换债务，那么这家公司并不会因此更富有，但在实际操作中，通过可转换债务筹集的资金与通过股权融资筹集的资金几乎没有区别。[2] 创始人经常对此感到惊讶，但投资者却可能变得非常情绪化。

paragraphs.original: Or rather indignant; that's the main emotion I've observed; but it is very common, to the point where it sometimes causes investors to act against their own interests. I know of one investor who invested in a startup at a $15 million valuation cap.
paragraphs.translated: 或者说愤怒；这是我观察到的主要情绪；而且非常普遍，有时甚至导致投资者做出违背自身利益的行为。我认识一位投资者，他在一家初创公司的估值上限为1500万美元时进行了投资。

paragraphs.original: Earlier he'd had an opportunity to invest at a $5 million cap, but he refused because a friend who invested earlier had been able to invest at a $3 million cap.[3] If an investor pushes you hard to tell them about your conversations with other investors, is this someone you want as an investor?
paragraphs.translated: 早些时候，他有一次以500万美元的估值上限进行投资的机会，但他拒绝了，因为一位先他投资的朋友是以300万美元的估值上限进行投资的。如果一位投资者强烈要求你透露与其他投资者的谈话内容，这是否是你想要的投资者？
